Award.AwardTitle: 3-D Mantle wedge flow pattern and seismic anisotropy: Effects of oblique subduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project looks to improve our understanding of the inner workings of subduction zones. The particular focus of this work on modeling the interface of two colliding plates, the mantle wedge, can help us to better understand how subduction zones are responsible for the location of volcanic arcs and how the conditions at that depth and composition can lead to earthquakes in areas like Hikurungi, Japan and the Aleutians, Alaska. The project will build a suite of 3D models and codes that The work will support a new researcher and a graduate student.

Shear waves splitting measurements indicate complex variations in the seismic anisotropy of the mantle wedge among different subduction zones. Deformation in the upper mantle causes seismic anisotropy through its effect on the lattice-preferred orientation (LPO) of anisotropic minerals and shape-preferred orientation of elastically distinct material, such as fluid-filled cracks. Earlier 3-D subduction modeling studies indicate that oblique subduction, 3-D slab geometry, and margin curvature cause complex spatial variations in mantle wedge flow directions, likely generating complex shear wave splitting patterns and making the interpretation of splitting
measurements difficult. In this study the researcher and graduate student will investigate the effect of 3-D mantle wedge flow patterns on the development of LPO and seismic anisotropy, focusing particularly on the role of oblique subduction. They will calculate mantle wedge flow fields for a range of subduction obliquity, slab geometry, and margin curvature. Using the calculated mantle flow field to compute LPO and shear wave splitting parameters the work will compare the calculated splitting parameter values with observation to systematically quantify the contributions of these factors to the observed anisotropic structures of mantle wedges globally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We computed the mantle flow field in the mantle wedge of subduction zones, using a suite of three-dimensional numerical models with a range of subduction obliquity, subduction parameters, slab geometry, and margin curvature. The models indicate that the mantle wedge flow pattern changes systematically with subduction obliquity, which is defined as the angle between the subduction direction and the strike-normal axis of the subducting slab. Further, an along-margin change in subduction obliquity due to the curvature of the subducting slab and the margin leads to along-margin changes in the mantle flow pattern and mantle wedge temperature.

Using the calculated mantle flow fields, we simulated the development of crystal preferred orientations (CPO) of olivine and calculated elastic tensors in the mantle wedge, using different olivine CPO fabric types. The results for A-type olivine fabric indicate that when subduction is oblique, the fast axis of olivine CPO does not align with the mantle flow direction in many parts of the mantle wedge and is highly spatially variable, making the common assumption of their alignment invalid. The results helped to quantitatively illustrate how the fast axis orientation changes spatially for different subduction obliquities and olivine fabric types.

Using the calculated elastic tensors, we computed two parameters that characterizes shear wave splitting through the mantle wedge: the fast direction and the delay time. The results indicate that for a given initial polarization of shear waves, the fast direction can change from the forearc to sub-arc to back-arc (e.g., margin-parallel to margin-normal to margin-oblique) without invoking different olivine fabric types. Further, although it is commonly assumed that the delay time should increase with the thickness of the mantle wedge, our results indicate that a noticeable increase in the delay time from forearc to the backarc does not necessarily occur. The results also indicate strong dependence of the fast direction on initial polarization. These results indicate that deciphering the mantle wedge signatures in the SWS observations is not simple and that better understanding of the occurrence of different olivine fabric types and identifying the initial polarization of shear waves are critical.

The thermal fields that are solved by the 3-D subduction models help to quantify the thermal effects of oblique subduction and mantle wedge flow and thus their impacts on temperature-dependent geophysical and geochemical processes, such earthquakes, dehydration, and melting. This project supported an early career female scientist and provided multidisciplinary training and learning opportunities for a graduate student in the fields of geodynamics, mineral physics, and seismology.
